paper_title: Metal-free Azo-bridged Porphyrin Porous Organic Polymers for Visible-light-driven CO 2 Reduction to CO with High Selectivity

catalyst.source: In a typical experiment, 4 mg of Azo-Por-X-POP catalyst (where X Bpy or Dadp) was dispersed in 3 mL of ethanol and sonicated for 120 min.
catalyst.context: TNPor was prepared according to published method. 30All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.As shown in Scheme 1, Azo-Por-Bpy-POP was synthesized by coupling TNPor and Bpy.Specifically, metal-free TNPor (0.15 mmol, 119.1 mg), Bpy (0.30 mmol, 56.07 mg), and KOH (7.55 mmol, 423 mg) were dispersed in 8 mL of nitrogen (N 2 )-purged dimethyl formamide (DMF).The mixture was stirred at 150C for 24 h under a N 2 atmosphere.Then the resulting mixture was cooled to room temperature and the dark purple solid was collected by filtration and washed by water.The residue was then immersed in DMF and allowed to stand for 24 h.The solid was then collected by filtration and washed with DMF, H 2 O, and methanol.The dark purple product was dried at 90C in a vacuum drying oven for 12 h, affording 136 mg of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP (yield 83).Following the same procedure, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP was obtained in the yield of 78. In a typical experiment, 4 mg of Azo-Por-X-POP catalyst (where X Bpy or Dadp) was dispersed in 3 mL of ethanol and sonicated for 120 min.The mixture was then deposited dropwisely onto a glass sheet with dimensions of 2.5 cm 2.5 cm.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was dried at 60C in a vacuum drying oven for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature before being subjected to tests.The average loading of the relevant catalyst was 0.2 mg.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was then loaded into a 475-mL-volume photoreactor, and 1.63 g of NaHCO 3 was placed uniformly at the bottom of the reactor, followed by thorough pumping vacuum at a section in Fig. S1B.Then, 5 mL of H 2 SO 4 (40) was injected into the vacuum photoreactor from b section in Fig. S1B to react with NaHCO 3 to afford 1 atm CO 2 gas, and the temperature was kept at 25 C using circulating water.After waiting 1 h to achieve the adsorption equilibrium of CO 2 on the surface of the polymer catalyst, the reactor was irradiated for the desired time using a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a cutoff filter ( 400 nm).This visible-light source was positioned 5 cm above the glass sheet in the reactor.After irradiating for a given time interval, 1.5 mL of the gaseous sample was extracted from c section of the reactor in Fig. S1B and analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector and high active Ni convertor (4890II, Beijing China Education Au-Light Co., Ltd., P. R. China) with N 2 as the carrier gas.

catalyst.source: Both POPs show high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO without requiring a sacrificial reagent or metal co-catalyst.
catalyst.context: Briefly summarizing above, two azo-bridged porphyrin POPs have been synthesized by coupling reactions.Both POPs show high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO without requiring a sacrificial reagent or metal co-catalyst.In particular, the large electrostatic interaction between CO 2 and the BPY-connected/attached porphyrin POP results in excellent photoreduction for CO 2 with 100 selectivity and good sustainability.The present result provides new insight for designing efficient photocatalytic polymers for solar-energy conversion. Scheme 1.The preparation of Azo-Por-X-POP by coupling reaction. Fig. 1. (A) FT-IR spectra of BPY, TNPP, and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; (B) 13 C CP-MAS NMR spectrum of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; XPS spectra of the N 1s region for (C) Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and (D) TNPor. Fig. 3. (A) N 2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP with pore size distribution shown inset; (B) CO 2 sorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP collected at 298 K; (C) UV-vis DRS spectra of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP, and TNPor; (D) Transient photocurrent responses of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP. May 2020.Downloaded by Uppsala University on 5/22/2020 9:24:43 AM.J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx 2.33 eV, Fig. 4D.The valence band (VB) Fig. 4. (A) CO 2 photoreduction performance for photocatalytic systems containing Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP and TNPor during a 4 h reaction; (B) Photocatalytic evolution of CO by Azo-Por-Bpy-POP under 1 atm, with stability tests of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP for the selective photoreduction of CO 2 shown inset; (C) Mott-Schottky plots of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, for electrodes in 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 at pH 6.8; (D) Tauc plot and extrapolated bandgap of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP. May 2020.Downloaded by Uppsala University on 5/22/2020 9:24:43 AM.View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/D0DT01436B Please do not adjust margins Please do not adjust margins Fig. 5. Electron density surfaces for (A) Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, (B) Azo-Por-Dadp-POP and (C) CO 2 .Red, green, and blue regions indicate negative, neutral, and positive electrostatic potentials, respectively.The binding energies (BE) of CO 2 and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP or Azo-Por-Dadp-POP in the Gibbs free energy and enthalpies (in parentheses) at three possible binding sites are given at the bottom.The electron density surfaces and binding energies were calculated at the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) level of theory, where the empirical dispersion was also considered. May 2020.Downloaded by Uppsala University on 5/22/2020 9:24:43 AM.View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/D0DT01436B This journal is The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. co-catalyst.source: Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP display high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO under visible-light irradiation without a sacrificial reagent or metal cocatalyst.
co-catalyst.context: Two nitrogen-rich azo-bridged porphyrin porous organic polymers (Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP) with high surface areas were prepared by coupling 5,10,15,20-tetra(p-nitrophenyl)-porphyrin with the aromatic amines of 2,2'bipyridine-5,5'-diamine (Bpy) and diaminodiphenyl (Dadp).Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP display high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO under visible-light irradiation without a sacrificial reagent or metal cocatalyst.Azo-Por-Bpy-POP exhibits the highest photoreduction for CO 2 with CO as the only carbonaceous reduction product with a production rate of 38.75 mol g -1 h -1 .Theoretical investigations indicate a stronger electrostatic interaction between CO 2 and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP than Azo-Por-Dadp-POP, which favors CO 2 photoreduction.

co-catalyst.source: Both POPs show high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO without requiring a sacrificial reagent or metal co-catalyst.
co-catalyst.context: Briefly summarizing above, two azo-bridged porphyrin POPs have been synthesized by coupling reactions.Both POPs show high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO without requiring a sacrificial reagent or metal co-catalyst.In particular, the large electrostatic interaction between CO 2 and the BPY-connected/attached porphyrin POP results in excellent photoreduction for CO 2 with 100 selectivity and good sustainability.The present result provides new insight for designing efficient photocatalytic polymers for solar-energy conversion. Scheme 1.The preparation of Azo-Por-X-POP by coupling reaction. Fig. 1. (A) FT-IR spectra of BPY, TNPP, and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; (B) 13 C CP-MAS NMR spectrum of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; XPS spectra of the N 1s region for (C) Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and (D) TNPor. Fig. 3. (A) N 2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP with pore size distribution shown inset; (B) CO 2 sorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP collected at 298 K; (C) UV-vis DRS spectra of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP, and TNPor; (D) Transient photocurrent responses of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP. light source.source: Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP display high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO under visible-light irradiation without a sacrificial reagent or metal cocatalyst.
light source.context: Two nitrogen-rich azo-bridged porphyrin porous organic polymers (Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP) with high surface areas were prepared by coupling 5,10,15,20-tetra(p-nitrophenyl)-porphyrin with the aromatic amines of 2,2'bipyridine-5,5'-diamine (Bpy) and diaminodiphenyl (Dadp).Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP display high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO under visible-light irradiation without a sacrificial reagent or metal cocatalyst.Azo-Por-Bpy-POP exhibits the highest photoreduction for CO 2 with CO as the only carbonaceous reduction product with a production rate of 38.75 mol g -1 h -1 .Theoretical investigations indicate a stronger electrostatic interaction between CO 2 and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP than Azo-Por-Dadp-POP, which favors CO 2 photoreduction.

light source.source: This visible-light source was positioned 5 cm above the glass sheet in the reactor.
light source.context: TNPor was prepared according to published method. 30All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.As shown in Scheme 1, Azo-Por-Bpy-POP was synthesized by coupling TNPor and Bpy.Specifically, metal-free TNPor (0.15 mmol, 119.1 mg), Bpy (0.30 mmol, 56.07 mg), and KOH (7.55 mmol, 423 mg) were dispersed in 8 mL of nitrogen (N 2 )-purged dimethyl formamide (DMF).The mixture was stirred at 150C for 24 h under a N 2 atmosphere.Then the resulting mixture was cooled to room temperature and the dark purple solid was collected by filtration and washed by water.The residue was then immersed in DMF and allowed to stand for 24 h.The solid was then collected by filtration and washed with DMF, H 2 O, and methanol.The dark purple product was dried at 90C in a vacuum drying oven for 12 h, affording 136 mg of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP (yield 83).Following the same procedure, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP was obtained in the yield of 78. In a typical experiment, 4 mg of Azo-Por-X-POP catalyst (where X Bpy or Dadp) was dispersed in 3 mL of ethanol and sonicated for 120 min.The mixture was then deposited dropwisely onto a glass sheet with dimensions of 2.5 cm 2.5 cm.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was dried at 60C in a vacuum drying oven for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature before being subjected to tests.The average loading of the relevant catalyst was 0.2 mg.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was then loaded into a 475-mL-volume photoreactor, and 1.63 g of NaHCO 3 was placed uniformly at the bottom of the reactor, followed by thorough pumping vacuum at a section in Fig. S1B.Then, 5 mL of H 2 SO 4 (40) was injected into the vacuum photoreactor from b section in Fig. S1B to react with NaHCO 3 to afford 1 atm CO 2 gas, and the temperature was kept at 25 C using circulating water.After waiting 1 h to achieve the adsorption equilibrium of CO 2 on the surface of the polymer catalyst, the reactor was irradiated for the desired time using a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a cutoff filter ( 400 nm).This visible-light source was positioned 5 cm above the glass sheet in the reactor.After irradiating for a given time interval, 1.5 mL of the gaseous sample was extracted from c section of the reactor in Fig. S1B and analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector and high active Ni convertor (4890II, Beijing China Education Au-Light Co., Ltd., P. R. China) with N 2 as the carrier gas.

light source.source: (C) UV-vis DRS spectra of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP, and TNPor
light source.context: Briefly summarizing above, two azo-bridged porphyrin POPs have been synthesized by coupling reactions.Both POPs show high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO without requiring a sacrificial reagent or metal co-catalyst.In particular, the large electrostatic interaction between CO 2 and the BPY-connected/attached porphyrin POP results in excellent photoreduction for CO 2 with 100 selectivity and good sustainability.The present result provides new insight for designing efficient photocatalytic polymers for solar-energy conversion. Scheme 1.The preparation of Azo-Por-X-POP by coupling reaction. Fig. 1. (A) FT-IR spectra of BPY, TNPP, and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; (B) 13 C CP-MAS NMR spectrum of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; XPS spectra of the N 1s region for (C) Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and (D) TNPor. Fig. 3. (A) N 2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP with pore size distribution shown inset; (B) CO 2 sorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP collected at 298 K; (C) UV-vis DRS spectra of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP, and TNPor; (D) Transient photocurrent responses of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP. lamp.source: After waiting 1 h to achieve the adsorption equilibrium of CO 2 on the surface of the polymer catalyst, the reactor was irradiated for the desired time using a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a cutoff filter ( 400 nm).
lamp.context: TNPor was prepared according to published method. 30All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.As shown in Scheme 1, Azo-Por-Bpy-POP was synthesized by coupling TNPor and Bpy.Specifically, metal-free TNPor (0.15 mmol, 119.1 mg), Bpy (0.30 mmol, 56.07 mg), and KOH (7.55 mmol, 423 mg) were dispersed in 8 mL of nitrogen (N 2 )-purged dimethyl formamide (DMF).The mixture was stirred at 150C for 24 h under a N 2 atmosphere.Then the resulting mixture was cooled to room temperature and the dark purple solid was collected by filtration and washed by water.The residue was then immersed in DMF and allowed to stand for 24 h.The solid was then collected by filtration and washed with DMF, H 2 O, and methanol.The dark purple product was dried at 90C in a vacuum drying oven for 12 h, affording 136 mg of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP (yield 83).Following the same procedure, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP was obtained in the yield of 78. In a typical experiment, 4 mg of Azo-Por-X-POP catalyst (where X Bpy or Dadp) was dispersed in 3 mL of ethanol and sonicated for 120 min.The mixture was then deposited dropwisely onto a glass sheet with dimensions of 2.5 cm 2.5 cm.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was dried at 60C in a vacuum drying oven for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature before being subjected to tests.The average loading of the relevant catalyst was 0.2 mg.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was then loaded into a 475-mL-volume photoreactor, and 1.63 g of NaHCO 3 was placed uniformly at the bottom of the reactor, followed by thorough pumping vacuum at a section in Fig. S1B.Then, 5 mL of H 2 SO 4 (40) was injected into the vacuum photoreactor from b section in Fig. S1B to react with NaHCO 3 to afford 1 atm CO 2 gas, and the temperature was kept at 25 C using circulating water.After waiting 1 h to achieve the adsorption equilibrium of CO 2 on the surface of the polymer catalyst, the reactor was irradiated for the desired time using a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a cutoff filter ( 400 nm).This visible-light source was positioned 5 cm above the glass sheet in the reactor.After irradiating for a given time interval, 1.5 mL of the gaseous sample was extracted from c section of the reactor in Fig. S1B and analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector and high active Ni convertor (4890II, Beijing China Education Au-Light Co., Ltd., P. R. China) with N 2 as the carrier gas.

lamp.source: The present result provides new insight for designing efficient photocatalytic polymers for solar-energy conversion.
lamp.context: Briefly summarizing above, two azo-bridged porphyrin POPs have been synthesized by coupling reactions.Both POPs show high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO without requiring a sacrificial reagent or metal co-catalyst.In particular, the large electrostatic interaction between CO 2 and the BPY-connected/attached porphyrin POP results in excellent photoreduction for CO 2 with 100 selectivity and good sustainability.The present result provides new insight for designing efficient photocatalytic polymers for solar-energy conversion. Scheme 1.The preparation of Azo-Por-X-POP by coupling reaction. Fig. 1. (A) FT-IR spectra of BPY, TNPP, and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; (B) 13 C CP-MAS NMR spectrum of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; XPS spectra of the N 1s region for (C) Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and (D) TNPor. Fig. 3. Electron density surfaces for (A) Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, (B) Azo-Por-Dadp-POP and (C) CO 2 .Red, green, and blue regions indicate negative, neutral, and positive electrostatic potentials, respectively.The binding energies (BE) of CO 2 and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP or Azo-Por-Dadp-POP in the Gibbs free energy and enthalpies (in parentheses) at three possible binding sites are given at the bottom.The electron density surfaces and binding energies were calculated at the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) level of theory, where the empirical dispersion was also considered. reactor type.source: The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was then loaded into a 475-mL-volume photoreactor, and 1.63 g of NaHCO 3 was placed uniformly at the bottom of the reactor, followed by thorough pumping vacuum at a section in Fig. S1B.
reactor type.context: TNPor was prepared according to published method. 30All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.As shown in Scheme 1, Azo-Por-Bpy-POP was synthesized by coupling TNPor and Bpy.Specifically, metal-free TNPor (0.15 mmol, 119.1 mg), Bpy (0.30 mmol, 56.07 mg), and KOH (7.55 mmol, 423 mg) were dispersed in 8 mL of nitrogen (N 2 )-purged dimethyl formamide (DMF).The mixture was stirred at 150C for 24 h under a N 2 atmosphere.Then the resulting mixture was cooled to room temperature and the dark purple solid was collected by filtration and washed by water.The residue was then immersed in DMF and allowed to stand for 24 h.The solid was then collected by filtration and washed with DMF, H 2 O, and methanol.The dark purple product was dried at 90C in a vacuum drying oven for 12 h, affording 136 mg of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP (yield 83).Following the same procedure, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP was obtained in the yield of 78. In a typical experiment, 4 mg of Azo-Por-X-POP catalyst (where X Bpy or Dadp) was dispersed in 3 mL of ethanol and sonicated for 120 min.The mixture was then deposited dropwisely onto a glass sheet with dimensions of 2.5 cm 2.5 cm.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was dried at 60C in a vacuum drying oven for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature before being subjected to tests.The average loading of the relevant catalyst was 0.2 mg.The catalyst-loaded glass sheet was then loaded into a 475-mL-volume photoreactor, and 1.63 g of NaHCO 3 was placed uniformly at the bottom of the reactor, followed by thorough pumping vacuum at a section in Fig. S1B.Then, 5 mL of H 2 SO 4 (40) was injected into the vacuum photoreactor from b section in Fig. S1B to react with NaHCO 3 to afford 1 atm CO 2 gas, and the temperature was kept at 25 C using circulating water.After waiting 1 h to achieve the adsorption equilibrium of CO 2 on the surface of the polymer catalyst, the reactor was irradiated for the desired time using a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a cutoff filter ( 400 nm).This visible-light source was positioned 5 cm above the glass sheet in the reactor.After irradiating for a given time interval, 1.5 mL of the gaseous sample was extracted from c section of the reactor in Fig. S1B and analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector and high active Ni convertor (4890II, Beijing China Education Au-Light Co., Ltd., P. R. China) with N 2 as the carrier gas.

reactor type.source: The text does not explicitly mention the reactor type.
reactor type.context: Briefly summarizing above, two azo-bridged porphyrin POPs have been synthesized by coupling reactions.Both POPs show high photocatalytic reduction activity for CO 2 to CO without requiring a sacrificial reagent or metal co-catalyst.In particular, the large electrostatic interaction between CO 2 and the BPY-connected/attached porphyrin POP results in excellent photoreduction for CO 2 with 100 selectivity and good sustainability.The present result provides new insight for designing efficient photocatalytic polymers for solar-energy conversion. Scheme 1.The preparation of Azo-Por-X-POP by coupling reaction. Fig. 1. (A) FT-IR spectra of BPY, TNPP, and Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; (B) 13 C CP-MAS NMR spectrum of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP; XPS spectra of the N 1s region for (C) Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and (D) TNPor. Fig. 3. (A) N 2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP with pore size distribution shown inset; (B) CO 2 sorption isotherms of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP collected at 298 K; (C) UV-vis DRS spectra of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP, Azo-Por-Dadp-POP, and TNPor; (D) Transient photocurrent responses of Azo-Por-Bpy-POP and Azo-Por-Dadp-POP.
